questions.question: Which one of these was not a beach landing site in the Invasion of Normandy?
questions.tip: The Five D-Day beaches code names were: Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno and Sword

questions.question: Who discovered Penicillin?
questions.tip: Penicillin, the first true antibiotic, was discovered by Alexander Fleming, Professor of Bacteriology at St. Mary's Hospital in London in 1928.

questions.question: In what year did the Wall Street Crash take place?
questions.tip: The Wall Street Crash of 1929, also known as the Great Crash, the Crash of 29, or Black Tuesday, was a major American stock market crash that occurred in the autumn of 1929.

questions.question: Which of the following African countries was most successful in resisting colonization?
questions.tip: Ethiopia was able to negotiate alliances with the surrounding North African kingdoms and Russia, allowing it to be the only country in Africa to successfully withstand European colonialism

questions.question: Which of the following ancient peoples was NOT classified as Hellenic (Greek)?
questions.tip: Illyrians, were a group of Indo-European-speaking peoples who inhabited the western Balkan Peninsula in ancient times. They constituted one of the three main Paleo-Balkan populations, along with the Thracians and Greeks.

questions.question: Which famous world leader is famed for the saying, 'Let them eat cake', yet is rumored that he/she never said it at all?
questions.tip: Marie-Antoinette, the queen of France during the French Revolution. As the story goes, it was the queen's response upon being told that her starving peasant subjects had no bread.

questions.question: The collapse of the Soviet Union took place in which year?
questions.tip: The dissolution of the Soviet Union was the process of internal disintegration within the Soviet Union which resulted in the end of the country's and its federal government's existence as a sovereign state, thereby resulting in its constituent republics gaining full independence on 26 December 1991.

questions.question: How was Socrates executed?
questions.tip: He was found guilty of “impiety” and “corrupting the young”, sentenced to death, and then required to carry out his own execution by consuming a deadly potion of the poisonous plant hemlock.

questions.question: Who was among those killed in the 2010 Smolensk, Russia plane crash tragedy?
questions.tip: Lech Kaczyński, the fourth President of the Republic of Poland, died on 10 April 2010, after a Polish Air Force Tu-154 crashed outside of Smolensk, Russia

questions.question: What is the historical name of Sri Lanka?
questions.tip: Sri Lanka's government has decided to change the names of all state institutions still bearing the nation's former British colonial name, Ceylon.

questions.question: Painter Piet Mondrian (1872 - 1944) was a part of what movement?
questions.tip: Painter Piet Mondrian was known for contributing to the founding of Neoplasticism, that is based on absolute geometric rigor, the adoption of pure geometric forms, with particular interest in the horizontal and vertical line

questions.question: Which time signature is commonly known as 'Cut Time'
questions.tip: Cut Time is signified in music with 2/2, or 2 over 2. If we use our formula - we conclude that there are 2 beats in each measure and the half note will get the beat, since 2 = a half note.

questions.question: Which artist's studio was known as The Factory?
questions.tip: Warhol produced his silkscreened works in a studio dubbed “The Factory.” His first Factory was born in 1963 and located on East 47th Street in New York.

questions.question: What year did Albrecht Durer create the painting The Young Hare?
questions.tip: Young Hare (German: Feldhase) is a 1502 watercolour and bodycolour painting by German artist Albrecht Dürer. Painted in 1502 in his workshop

questions.question: Which of these are the name of a famous marker brand?
questions.tip: Copic brand is one of the most popular artist markers out there. An alcohol-based ink, the colors are non-toxic and are refillable once you've used all of the pigment

questions.question: Which artist's style was to use small different colored dots to create a picture?
questions.tip: Georges Seurat and Paul Signac developed the technique in 1886, branching from Impressionism. The term 'Pointillism' was coined by art critics in the late 1880s to ridicule the works of these artists, but is now used without its earlier pejorative connotation.

questions.question: Which of these is not an additional variation of the color purple?
questions.tip: The color kobicha (媚茶) is one of the Japanese traditional colors that has been in use since 660 CE in the form of various dyes used in designing kimonos.

questions.question: Who designed the Chupa Chups logo?
questions.tip: The Chupa Chups logo was designed in 1969 by the surrealist artist Salvador Dalí. Its first marketing campaign was the logo with the slogan 'Es redondo y dura mucho, Chupa Chups', which translates from Spanish as 'It's round and long-lasting'

questions.question: The painting 'The Starry Night' by Vincent van Gogh was part of which art movement?
questions.tip: You Figured it out! Good job!

questions.question: Who painted the epic mural Guernica?
questions.tip: The Starry Night (1889) painting is a famous oil painting by Vincent van Gogh, who was part of the Post-Impressionism art movement during the 19th century.

questions.question: The derisive acronym 'PIIGS' refers to which of the following European countries and their economic statuses?
questions.tip: PIIGS is a derisive acronym for Portugal, Italy, Ireland, Greece, and Spain, which were the weakest economies in the eurozone during the European debt crisis.

questions.question: What is the capital of Senegal?
questions.tip: Dakar, that is a vibrant city famous for its lively markets and rich musical culture.

questions.question: What is the most populous Muslim-majority nation in 2022?
questions.tip: The largest Muslim population in a country is in Indonesia, a country home to 12.7% of the world's Muslims, followed by Pakistan (11.1%), India (10.9%) and Bangladesh (9.2%). About 20% of Muslims live in the Arab world.

questions.question: What is the official German name of the Swiss Federal Railways?
questions.tip: Schweizerische Bundesbahnen was formed in 2005 from the merger of two companies: a different SBB GmbH, and EuroTHURBO . Swiss Federal Railways founded the original SBB GmbH in 2002 to operate the S5 and S6 services of the Basel S-Bahn.

questions.question: What is the capital of the US State of New York?
questions.tip: Albany is located in the Hudson Valley, surrounded by mountain ranges. The city lies at the west bank of the Hudson River in the eastern part of New York state

questions.question: What is the name of the largest river to flow through Paris?
questions.tip: The Seine River crosses several important urbanized areas of France. With a length of 754 km, it originates near Dijon, flows through Paris, and discharges to the English Channel. The basin drainage area is approximately 75,976 km².

questions.question: Mount Vesuvius casts a shadow over which modern Italian city?
questions.tip: Mt Vesuvius dominates the skyline of Naples and the surrounding Italian countryside, a reminder of its devastating effect on the town of Pompeii,

questions.question: Which country has the longest coastline in the world?
questions.tip: Coastline: Canada's coastline is the world's longest, measuring 243,042 km (includes the mainland coast and the coasts of offshore islands).

questions.question: In which city would you find La Sagrada Familia?
questions.tip: Sagrada Família, is an unfinished church in the Eixample district of Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain. It is the largest unfinished Catholic church in the world.

questions.question: The Strait of Gibraltar separates the Iberian Peninsular from which African country or countries?
questions.tip: On the northern side of the Strait are Spain and Gibraltar (a British overseas territory in the Iberian Peninsula), while on the southern side are Morocco and Ceuta

questions.question: Identify the noun in the following sentence: The mailman Mr. Joe was carrying postcards.
questions.tip: Mailman, Mr. Joe and postcards - NOUN is a word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).

questions.question: Identify the pronoun in the following sentence: Everyone is sleeping in the dorm room
questions.tip: Everyone - A PRONOUN is a word that is used instead of a noun or noun phrase. Pronouns refer to either a noun that has already been mentioned or to a noun that does not need to be named specifically.

questions.question: Identify the verb in the following sentence: She bought a new car and started taking her driving lessons.
questions.tip: Bought, started, taking - Verbs are words that show an action (sing), occurrence (develop), or state of being (exist). Almost every sentence requires a verb.

questions.question: Identify the Adverb in the following sentence: The dog looked at his owner curiously.
questions.tip: Curiously - ADVERB is a word or phrase that modifies or qualifies an adjective, verb, or other adverb or a word group, expressing a relation of place, time, circumstance, manner, cause, degree, etc.

questions.question: Identify the adjective in the following sentence: Linda McKenzie has five children
questions.tip: Five - ADJECTIVE is a word naming an attribute of a noun, such as sweet, red, or technical.

questions.question: Identify present, past or future tense from the following sentence: It rained heavily.
questions.tip: Simple Past - The simple past is a verb tense that is used to talk about things that happened or existed before now

questions.question: Identify the correct sentence.
questions.1: The weather is wet windy, unpredictable.
questions.2: The weather is wet, windy, unpredictable.
questions.3: The weather is wet, and windy and unpredictable.
questions.4: The weather is wet, windy and unpredictable.
questions.tip: D - Punctuation is defined as a set of symbols used to separate and clarify the meaning of sentences and written elements.

questions.question: Identify the correct sentence.
questions.1: Dont worry, every little thing is going to be alright.
questions.2: Don’t worry. Every little thing is going to be alright.
questions.3: Don’t worry every little thing is going to be alright
questions.4: Dont worry, every little thing is gonna be alright
questions.tip: B - Punctuation tells readers of your writing where to pause, what words are quotations and which are clarifications, where words have been omitted, and more.

questions.question: Identify the preposition in the following sentence: The kids are sitting around the block.
questions.tip: Around - A preposition is a word—and almost always a very small, very common word—that shows direction (to in 'a letter to you'), location (at in 'at the door')

questions.question: Identify the synonym from the option given below: Nice
questions.tip: Pleasant - SYNONYM word or phrase that means exactly or nearly the same as another word or phrase in the same language

questions.question: Which one of the following is a legal responsibility?
questions.1: Making sure your children get an education if you are a parent.
questions.2: Locking your car after parking it if you are a motorist.
questions.3: Making sure all your employees receive regular training if you are an employer.
questions.4: Caring for your partner if they are ill.
questions.tip: All parents have a legal duty to ensure that their child receives an education suitable to his/her age, ability and aptitude and any special needs. Most parents fulfil their legal obligation by registering their child in a school.

questions.question: Identify one characteristics for possible discrimination protected by the Equality Act.
questions.tip: Characteristics that the Equality Act protects are age, disability, gender reassignment, marriage and civil partnership, pregnancy and maternity, race, religion or belief, sex, and sexual orientation.

questions.question: Which reason best explains why the age of criminal responsibility is different in different countries?
questions.1: Governments have different amounts of youth crime to deal with.
questions.2: Some governments are signed up to the ‘United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child’ but others are not.
questions.3: Governments in Less Economically Developed Countries (LEDCs) sometimes don’t have courts suitable for trials of young people.
questions.4: Governments hold different views about the age at which children understand the impact of their actions on others.
questions.tip: The age of criminal responsibility is the age below which a child is deemed incapable of having committed a criminal offence.

questions.question: When would a democratic government usually restrict freedom of speech?
questions.3: when jokes are made about politicians and religious leaders
questions.4: when individuals are at risk of significant damage
questions.tip: Public authorities may restrict this right if they can show that their action is lawful, necessary and proportionate in order to: protect national security, territorial integrity (the borders of the state) or public safety. prevent disorder or crime. protect health or morals.

questions.question: Which piece of evidence is the most useful in deciding whether a law is working?
questions.4: Judges say that the law is easy to understand.
questions.tip: Police recorded crime in England and Wales in the year ending September 2022 exceeded pre-coronavirus pandemic levels. The 6.6 million crimes recorded were 10% higher compared with the year ending March 2020 (6.1 million offences)

questions.question: Which reason best explains why a person accused of an offence would seek advice from a solicitor?
questions.1: Solicitors can provide legal aid to help with costs.
questions.2: Solicitors can use their legal powers to settle disputes.
questions.3: Solicitors provide free advice and only charge to represent people in court.
questions.4: Solicitors are independent of the police, government and local authorities
questions.tip: Solicitors can represent you to make sure your legal rights are protected and to present your case in court to make sure you get a fair hearing.

questions.question: Which responsibility is carried out by devolved governments in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland?
questions.tip: Handling legislation as it affects the territory. representing the territory's interests in cabinet and cabinet committees. responding to parliamentary interests in territorial affairs. transmitting the block grant to the devolved administration.

questions.question: Which reason best explains why a coalition government would be formed?
questions.1: one political party wants to form a government on its own but did not win a majority following an election
questions.2: one political party gained a majority following an election and wants to form a government on its own
questions.3: no single political party gained an overall majority following an election
questions.4: two political parties gain equal votes following an election and cannot agree who should form the government
questions.tip: A coalition government might also be created in a time of national difficulty or crisis, to give a government the high degree of perceived political legitimacy or collective identity, it can also play a role in diminishing internal political strife.

questions.question: Which reason best explains why cabinet government is favoured in the United Kingdom (UK)?
questions.1: Different interest groups can be represented by all the political parties in the cabinet.
questions.2: Ministers can make better decisions by discussing them with colleagues.
questions.3: Civil servants and politicians can have an equal say.
questions.4: The devolved governments of Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland can be properly represented.
questions.tip: Members run departments and are drawn from Parliament, and all ministers have an equal say in policy decisions, including the PM

questions.question: What is Black Rod’s ceremonial role in Parliament?
questions.1: Calling MPs to attend the House of Lords
questions.4: Making sure MPs speak in the correct order
questions.tip: Black Rod is sent from the Lords Chamber to the Commons Chamber to summon MPs to hear the King's Speech. Traditionally the door of the Commons is slammed in Black Rod's face to symbolise the Commons independence. He or she then bangs three times on the door with the rod.
